data.title: Eastern White Cedar
data.subtitle: Here, the trail passes through a section of the forest that is predominantly Eastern White Cedar.

contents.content_before_fold:
Trees in our northern climate that retain their leaves year-round, such as cedars, pine and spruce, are called “evergreen” or “coniferous” – the latter referring to their shared tendency to produce their seeds in cones. Coniferous forest, like the patch of Eastern White Cedar (Thuja occidentalis) which surrounds you now, provides valuable winter habitat for wildlife.

In winter, White-tailed Deer (Odocoileus virginianus) use coniferous forest as “yarding areas” – congregating below heavy evergreen boughs as they seek refuge from strong winds and deep snow. Although not as nutritious and digestible as their summer foods, cedar leaves also provide sustenance to deer. Two other key features of deer yards are their tendency to be located on south-facing slopes and their relative lack of human disturbance. Visitors exploring this section of trail in winter will notice numerous tracks zig-zagging in the snow providing evidence that many deer use this patch of forest as a yarding area.
contents.content_after_fold:
Other evidence of deer using an area are small trees whose bark has been rubbed off by male deer preparing to shed their antlers, as well as large, oval-shaped depressions in the snow where deer have bedded down for the night.

While you may not catch a glimpse of any deer, the silence of winter may be broken when you find yourself startled by the loud wingbeats of a Ruffed Grouse (Bonasa umbellus) bursting suddenly out of the snow. Grouse will take advantage of the insulating properties of the snow to stay warm on cold winter nights, by burying themselves under fresh snow; doing so also helps hide them from hungry predators. Year-round, listen for the nasal “aaaank… aaaank… aaaank” call of the Red-breasted Nuthatch (Sitta canadensis), or chattering trill of the Red Squirrel (Tamiasciurus hudsonicus), both of which call coniferous forests home. Interspersed through this predominantly coniferous patch of forest are some deciduous (leaf-shedding) trees, notably White Oak (Quercus alba) on the higher elevations, and several White Birch (Betula papyrifera, also called Paper Birch) toward the southern end.

1. Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources. 1997. Guidelines for Winter Feeding of Deer in Ontario. Queen’s Printer for Ontario. 8 pp.

contents.title: Gallery 1
contents.description: Have a look at what our hidden trail camera photographed at this deer yard! (swipe the images to move around in the galleries)

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question: Q: On the coldest of nights, how might the temperature of this coniferous deer yard compare with the air temperature in the open rock barren on the ridge to the east?
contents.answer: A: Especially on windy nights, temperatures beneath the conifers can be significantly warmer in comparison with that of open areas – up to ten degrees Centigrade warmer1, even!

options.label: So much colder here, in this low, dark area!
No difference.  Cold is cold is cold!!
Nice and sheltered, and somewhat warmer.

data.title: Climate Monitoring Station
data.long_title: Our Local Climate - Right Here, Right Now!
data.subtitle: This small point of land is more than just a picnic area; it provides views of Elbow Lake’s satellite-linked climate-monitoring station.

contents.content_before_fold:
At the north end of the lake, a raft over the deepest part of Elbow Lake (just under 9 m or about 29 ft in depth) supports one of seven climate monitoring stations located across QUBS properties with one additional site within Thousand Islands National Park on the St. Lawrence River.

Stations are positioned to compare lakes both within the same latitude, as well as lakes across different latitudes. (Credit: SutronWIN)

From the raft, the Elbow Lake station monitors ambient air temperature; relative humidity (RH); wind speed, direction and gusts; barometric pressure; and water temperature both near the surface (1.1 m depth) and 2 metres below. In addition to these climate data, the Elbow Lake station gathers water temperature data below the orange buoy at 15 depth intervals ranging from 0.25 m to 9 m, and measures dissolved oxygen at 1 m depth. Land-based gauges monitor precipitation from the adjacent shoreline, and record soil temperature 5 cm and 15 centimetres below the surface.

Measurements are collected frequently, enabling researchers to track changes in local climate in real-time over time intervals as short as 15 minutes. Climate data are relayed via satellite to a central server, where they are immediately available online for use by researchers worldwide! In time we will have these data available in real-time on a screen in the lodge. Data from these stations are being used to study changes in local climate and their influence on ecosystems and individual species.

Example air temperature data from the Elbow Lake climate station, July 2014.

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question:
Q: To gather climate data, each station is adorned with a number of measuring gauges and sensors, as well as the devices that power the station, and configure and transmit the information. Can you match each component of Elbow Lake’s monitoring station with its specific purpose?

Drawing from this list, match the numbered component on the climate station to its purpose:
contents.answer: The bulk of the climate station is devoted to the computer “brain box”, which is powered by a solar-charged battery. Climate information gathered by sensors at both the highest tip of the floating station and attached to a submersed cable (this passes through the black pipe protruding through the raft) is assembled by the computer and data are relayed via the antenna to a geostationary satellite. On land, a simple, solar-powered funnel gauge collects rain and snow (the latter is melted by a heater cord), measuring and recording 1 mL increments. Subsurface sensors also record soil temperatures precipitation and soil data are not connected to the satellite, and must be downloaded manually.

data.title: EMAN Forest Survey
data.subtitle: Elbow Lake is to the east; to the west is a forested area.  Here, just beyond the ridge, is a small area where the health of the forest is being assessed.

contents.content_before_fold:
Through the Ecological Monitoring and Assessment Network (EMAN), forest biodiversity has been monitored from one nearby plot since 2008.  Research volunteers visit this site each year in late September, and while not all of the EMAN protocol indicators of biodiversity and forest health are surveyed, the volunteers monitor the health and growth of tagged trees with diameters larger than 4 cm, as well as rates of decay of woody debris, and seedling growth.

Up until 2015, the most common tree in the forest biodiversity plot is ash – both White Ash (Fraxinus americana) and Green Ash (Fraxinus pennsylvanica) – while Red Oak (Quercus rubra), Basswood (Tilia americana) and White Pine (Pinus strobus) are tied for 2nd most common.  With the arrival of the non-native, invasive Emerald Ash Borer beetle (Agrilus planipennis) to Frontenac County in 2012, the continued survival and existence of our ash trees is at risk.  The EMAN forest biodiversity monitoring plot will help researchers quantify changes to the health of our trees – as well as changes to the relative composition of forest species – over time.  Ten years from now, will Red Oak and Basswood dominate the forest around you?
contents.content_after_fold:
Once coordinated by Environment Canada, EMAN's role was to establish scientifically-sound biodiversity monitoring protocols, and disseminate these to a network of partners – provincial parks, conservation authorities, Citizen Scientists – through training and staff support.  Partners would take responsibility for the on-the-ground monitoring, using the standardized EMAN protocols.  A victim of government cuts, EMAN is no longer in existence, although many partners have continued long-term biodiversity monitoring using EMAN protocols.

Data gathered at the Elbow Lake forest biodiversity plot are stored with Parks Canada and incorporated into analyses of the greater ecosystem surrounding Thousand Islands National Park, as they watch for trends in forest health within the larger landscape.  Along with a small number of other active forest biodiversity plots in the area, the Elbow Lake site contributes information on ecosystem health of one of the most forested areas of Ontario and an important area of the Frontenac Arch.

contents.question: Q: The EMAN protocol sets a minimum size to the trees being monitored at each plot; at the Elbow Lake site, a tree within the plot must have a minimum diameter of 4 cm (measured at “breast height”, or 4.5 ft / 1.3 m above the ground) to be counted in biodiversity and health measurements. Look at the graph of tagged trees – those with diameters of 4 cm or larger: What trend(s) can you see? Select all that apply:
contents.answer: A: Over time, the forest is maturing: There are more large trees in the Elbow Lake EMAN plot than there were in 2008, the first year of monitoring. As more trees surpass the minimum size threshold, more trees are being included in monitoring – leading to better information on the health and diversity of the forest around us.

options.label: The overall size of trees in the plot is increasing.
Trees in this plot are dying off; fewer large trees remain.
More trees are currently being monitored than when the project first began in 2008.
Researchers have been monitoring the same number of trees since 2008.

data.title: Pink Lady's Slipper Orchid
data.subtitle: To one side of the trail, visitors enjoy views of the pond.  To the other side, scrutiny of the forest floor may yield views of less immediately apparent beauty… (header photo by Mark Conboy)

contents.content_before_fold:
Delicate Pink Lady’s Slipper (Cypripedium acaule) orchids grow among the dappled sunshine under the pines, blooming typically in June, although the relatively large, oblong leaves with their distinct, parallel veins are usually visible until July, after which drought or disease cause them to disappear; occasionally Pink Lady’s Slipper leaves last into September. In years of less-than-ideal conditions – for example, in the cold, dry spring of 2015 – these orchids may not bloom at all.

Plants in the orchid family (Orchidaceae) are heavily dependent on other organisms to survive and reproduce. Like most orchids, Pink Lady’s Slipper seeds do not contain nutrients and thus rely on the threadlike filaments (or hyphae) of fungi to both break open the seed and supply them with nutrients. As the plant matures, nutrients produced by the Pink Lady’s Slipper flow through its roots and will help feed the associated fungus. Through this unique symbiotic relationship, the orchid and the fungus co-exist.
contents.content_after_fold:
Like many other orchid species, lady’s slipper orchids have an unusual pollination strategy: Their closed, “pouched” flower – with its resemblance to a woman’s slipper – has a slit through which insects like bees enter and become temporarily trapped, with the only exit being via a tube at the top of the flower. In passing through this tube, the bee encounters the orchid’s reproductive parts and brushes against the pollen. The sticky pollen travels with the bee as it visits another orchid, where again the bee is trapped while pollen is advertently transferred to the reproductive parts of the next plant, resulting in fertilization.

Pink Lady’s Slippers are perennial and may live up to two decades.

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question: Q: Prized for their beauty, wild populations of lady’s slipper orchids are at risk. Of the five species found in Eastern Ontario, only the Pink Lady’s Slipper is known to occur on the Elbow Lake property, where it is protected as part of the nature reserve. What do you think might be the greatest threat to this particular patch of wild orchids?
contents.answer: A: Some individual plants may be inadvertently trampled by visitors wandering off-trail, and the worldwide decline in pollinators is an imminent threat to most flowering plants including orchids. However, should anyone dig up these lovely orchids for their own garden, this population could be permanently lost to future generations. Wild plant collecting is a common threat to most orchid species, despite the fact that they don’t transplant well, mostly due to the damaging impacts that digging has on the root system. A better option for decorating your woodland garden is to purchase commercially-grown Pink Lady’s Slipper from a reputable nursery instead.

options.label: Decline in insect pollinators such as bees
Illegal collection of this plant for personal use

data.title: Wetland Life
data.subtitle: Behold nature's hub of life! The boardwalk ahead of you crosses one of the many wetland communities on the Elbow Lake property.

contents.content_before_fold:
Five main wetland types are found in Ontario: Marsh, Swamp, Fen, Bog and Shallow/Open water. The wetland community here is dominated by grasses, rushes and reeds, which means that it can be classified as a marsh. There is a huge variety of marsh types, but all provide habitat for many plants, animals and insects. This particular marsh is called a Three-square Mineral Shallow Marsh Type – can you spot the Three-way Sedge (Dulichium arundinaceum) the dominant plant that distinguishes this wetland type?

Alive with activity and sound, listen for the calls of Red-winged Blackbirds (Agelaius phoeniceus) and Spring Peepers (Pseudacris crucifer) in early spring to remind you that Ol’ Man Winter is on his way out.

Spring Peeper (Pseudacris crucifer) Calling

(click here to play if the above file does not work)
contents.content_after_fold:
Why are wetlands important?

Wetlands are rich ecosystems that are unique because they are where land and water habitats meet, creating a home for hundreds of different species. Many of these species can live no where else and are now at risk in Ontario and Canada because of the extensive loss of wetland habitat. Wetlands, like the one in front of you, support species-at-risk like the threatened Blanding’s Turtle (Emydoidea blandingii). These yellow-chinned beauties have been found on the Elbow Lake property. During nesting season (late May to early June) Blanding’s Turtles may travel hundreds of meters to find a mate and nest. This is why it is so important to not only protect the wetland, but also the surrounding upland habitat. Fun fact – Blanding’s Turtles are one of the longest living freshwater turtle and can live up to 75 years in the wild!! Other species at risk that are supported by wetland habitats include Eastern Ribbonsnake (Thamnophis sauritus sauritus), Boreal Chorus Frog (Pseudacris maculata), Snapping Turtle (Chelydra serpentine) and Black Tern (Childonias niger) – all of which are protected on the Elbow Lake property.

What is NCC doing?

Wetlands occupy 6% of the Earth's land and freshwater surface and help to purify water, control erosion and run-off, house biodiversity, and provide refuge and water for terrestrial animals. Canada has 25% of the planet's wetlands, but an estimated 72% of wetlands in southern Ontario have been lost. The Nature Conservancy of Canada (NCC) has been protecting wetlands for more than 40 years, with the conservation of its first successful project, Ontario's Cavan Swamp and Bog, in 1968. In addition to securing wetlands, NCC has been involved in restoring, reclaiming and managing them for the long-term benefit of wildlife and humans.

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question: Q: Which of the following do you think is not a wetland community?
contents.answer:
A: Though Alvars are a type of habitat, they are not a wetland, but rather naturally open terrestrial areas with shallow soil or even no soil over a limestone base. The Elbow Lake property, with its granite base, does not have Alvars.

Of Ontario’s five main wetland communities, Bogs and Fens are rare in the southern reaches of the province, and neither is found on the Elbow Lake property although Marshes, Swamps and Shallow/Open Water are common, comprising approximately 25% of the property. All communities can be further classified down to a type, based on the vegetation found within and soil characteristics. Learn more about wetlands at www.ducks.ca/learn-about-wetlands/what-wetland/

data.title: Logging
data.subtitle: From this wide, road-like section of trail, we can see evidence that suggests that the Elbow Lake property was once logged. (header image courtesy of Mark Conboy)

contents.content_before_fold:
More than 200 years ago, the granite and gneiss of the Precambrian Shield bedrock supported large stands of mature forest. Hemlock, sugar maple, white pine, basswood and cedar were the dominant tree species, according to Crown Land surveyors’ records from the late 1700s. Despite the incredibly rugged terrain of the Frontenac Arch landscape, very little has evaded the impacts of human settlement, past or present. With its historically rich timber and mineral resources, logging and mining provided important resources that sustained early European settlers. However, by 1880, over 70% of eastern Ontario’s forests had been cleared.

The dominant tree species in the exclusively deciduous forest around you are Ironwood (Ostrya virginiana, also known as Hop-hornbeam) and Red Oak (Quercus rubra), although some Sugar Maple (Acer saccharum) and the occasional Shagbark Hickory (Carya ovata) are also present. Research1 shows that species such as White Pine have declined by over 50% in today’s forests from those past; coupled with a loss of the seed bed from post-logging burns and lack of parent sources (i.e. mature trees), probably only conscious restoration efforts could ever bring back our current deciduous and mixed forests to their historic, pre-European settlement composition.
contents.content_after_fold:
While there are a few large, mature oaks to be found, most of the trees here are small – the Ironwoods are generally less than 12 centimetres (about 5 inches) in diameter, the Sugar Maples hardly larger than 25 centimetres (10 inches) in diameter – and of relatively similar size. Referred to as an “even-aged stand”, these trees germinated at the same time, their seedlings likely taking advantage of the light and space left behind after the competition was harvested. Ironwood does not have a very high commercial value, so would not have been selected for timber. Although commercial logging has not occurred here for over 50 years, the rocky landscape and shallow soils of the Frontenac Arch make it challenging for forests to recover from its impacts.

1. Thompson, I.D., Simard, J.H. and Titman, R.D. 2006. Historical Changes in White Pine (Pinus strobus) Density in Algonquin Park, Ontario, During the 19th Century. Natural Areas Journal, 26(1): 61-71.

data.title: Eastern Pondmussel
data.subtitle: This pile of clamshells at the water’s edge, leftovers from a hungry rodent’s dinner, tells us about the different species of mussel that are found in Elbow Lake.

contents.content_before_fold:
In 2005, a population of the now federally-Endangered Eastern Pondmussel (Ligumia nasuta) was discovered in Lyn Creek near Brockville, encouraging surveys of other possible surviving populations in the lower Great Lakes area. Shells have been found at a few lakes on the Frontenac Arch lending hope that the Eastern Pondmussel might still be present in waterbodies not yet invaded by non-native Zebra Mussels (Dreissena poymorpha).

Extensive searching of pristine Elbow Lake in 2012 and 2103 found only the common Eastern Elliptio (Elliptio companata). The search for remaining populations of the Eastern Pondmussel, led by two independent researchers from the Bishop’s Mills Natural History Centre near Kemptville, continues in lakes in the Frontenac Arch.

One Eastern Pondmussel shell was found in nearby, Zebra-devastated Loughborough Lake in 2009. This led to the search for them upstream in Fishing Lake, whose water may be so low in calcium that the thick-shelled Zebra Mussels wouldn’t be able to survive. Success! In May 2015, Eastern Pondmussel was confirmed to persist in Fishing Lake.
contents.content_after_fold:
Once among the most common species of freshwater mussels in the lower Great Lakes of Ontario, the Eastern Pondmussel has experienced severe population declines due to mortality associated with Zebra Mussel infestation. Zebra Mussels adhere to any solid substrate in their aquatic environment: be it rock, dock, or the shells of other molluscs. In the latter case, the inadvertent host is smothered and starved by masses of the much smaller Zebra Mussel cementing their shells shut, effectively preventing their host breathing and feeding. Zebra Mussels also compete with native mussels for food.

As filter feeders, clams and other molluscs play an important role in purifying the aquatic ecosystem, and provide an important food source for larger predators, particularly Muskrat and Beaver. Here, it appears that Muskrats are the main predator, as the shells in the midden piles are rarely broken. Muskrats bring live mussels up onto land at their favorite feasting places on the bank, leave them open for hours or even days until they start to gape for oxygen, and then come back to pry the shells apart with their long, straight claws, and eat the mussel bodies.

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question: Q: The larvae of our native freshwater mussels live as tiny parasites on the gills and fins of fish, which allows native mussels to disperse upstream. Larvae of the invasive Zebra Mussel are planktonic, meaning they float freely in the water column. How then, might Zebra Mussels disperse to other waterbodies?
contents.answer: A: While Zebra Mussel larvae are able to disperse downstream to adjacent lakes and rivers, the only way this species is able to travel upstream or over land is through human-related activity. The microscopic larvae may catch a ride in the live well of your fishing boat, while adult Zebra Mussels, with their ability to adhere to hard surfaces and temporarily survive out of water, may hitchhike on the bottom of your boat – including canoes and kayaks – or personal watercraft.

options.label: Evaporate with water vapour and rain down somewhere else
Flow with the current to downstream waterbodies

data.title: Eastern White Pine
data.long_title: A Proud Symbol of Ontario - and ELEEC!
data.subtitle: As you travel through the forest, one species of evergreen tree can be seen dominating the southeast shorelines or towering above its neighbours.

contents.content_before_fold:
The Eastern White Pine (Pinus strobus) is a prominent species in the extensive mixed forests of eastern North America, including the Elbow Lake property. Like all pines, its leaves are needles – the distinguishing characteristics being that Eastern White Pine’s needles are relatively long and slender, and assembled in bunches of five.

The pines you see growing around here are typically much smaller and younger than those that would have been present historically. While today’s largest specimens can reach 50 m in height (the equivalent of a 15-story building) and exceed 400 years in age, we know from historical records that the first human settlers encountered Eastern White Pine that were 40% larger than this!

Not only is the Eastern White Pine the official tree of the Province of Ontario (as declared on May 1, 1984), the silhouette of this majestic species also represents the Elbow Lake property in the Elbow Lake Environmental Education Centre logo.
contents.content_after_fold:
When sailing ships ruled the seas and Great Lakes, the long, tall White Pine was prized for masts, with the cream of the crop reserved for British Navy ships. Logging activity by early European settlers, however, not only removed the largest trees from the landscape but contributed to an overall 50% decline in the number of White Pine growing in southern Ontario forests1. Today, the wood remains highly valued for furniture and house construction. White Pine also provides shelter and food for many animal species, including winter finches and squirrels.

1. Thompson, I.D., Simard, J.H. and Titman, R.D. 2006. Historical Changes in White Pine (Pinus strobus) Density in Algonquin Park, Ontario, During the 19th Century. Natural Areas Journal, 26(1): 61-71.

contents.content_before_fold: Not only can Eastern White Pine tower above the other trees in the forest, its trunk can reach sizeable thickness as well. While large specimens can measure 3-5 metres around, a typical mature tree that is 20-35 metres tall will have a circumference (girth) of 2-4½ metres. One nearby Eastern White Pine has a measuring tape attached at chest height (approximately 4.5 ft or 1.3 m): What is its girth, and how might the other Eastern White Pine around you compare?

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question: Q: Today’s mature Eastern White Pine have diameters of at least 60 centimetres (24 inches). From this station waypoint, you can probably see three mature trees (as of 2015). One hundred years ago, prior to this area being logged, how many mature Eastern White Pine might have been counted in this area?
contents.answer: A: If human impacts in this area were typical of other regions in the province, then prior to European settlement there would have been approximately twice as many Eastern White Pine – or six mature trees – visible from this location.

options.label: None - These three trees would have not yet reached maturity
Same number - Logging had no impact on tree species distribution
Twice as many - The abundance of this species declined by half following logging
Five times as many - Eastern White Pine once dominated the forest!

data.title: Frontenac Arch Geology
data.subtitle: Some would describe the Canadian Shield as a rugged landscape, but its current topography is much gentler than what was present here billions of years ago.

contents.content_before_fold:
The Canadian Shield is the ancient geological core of North America, whose exposed rocks and thin soils underlie nearly half our country. The Elbow Lake property is situated within a landscape feature known as the Frontenac Arch, a part of the Grenville Structural Province which is the youngest part of the Canadian Shield – and essentially the roots of a former mountain range!

Approximately 1.1 billion years ago, the Grenville Mountains were in their prime, with peaks of up to 7 km high rivaling those of today’s Himalayan Mountains. But, by 500 million years ago, the Grenville Mountains had completely eroded away, leaving behind a low-relief, barren landscape covered with sand and boulders that would eventually become the sedimentary rocks sandstone and conglomerate. After this time, around 470 million years ago, this entire area was submerged by ocean; as the water receded, lime mud and sediments composed primarily of the calcium carbonate shells of marine organisms turned into the limestone that sits on top of the shield rocks to the west of the Frontenac Arch.

Not surprisingly, considering the history of the Frontenac Arch's formation, the primary rock on the Elbow Lake property is amphibolite gneiss, a metamorphic rock. Metamorphic rocks are ones modified by heat, pressure or chemical processes while buried deep below the Earth's crust.  The Grenville Mountains were believed to have been formed by the collision between two early continents, thus their metamorphic rocks would have been formed by intense pressure. From geological Map 2054, we see how different the Frontenac Arch landscape on and around the Elbow Lake property is compared to the limestones of nearby Kingston to the southwest, or the dolomite sandstones blanketing the shield to the northeast.
contents.content_after_fold: The Frontenac Arch extends to the Adirondack Mountains of New York State, bringing aspects of northern Canadian Shield to more southern climes. In this narrow band of habitat, five forest regions merge; boreal species intermingle with Carolinian species, and a tremendous biodiversity of flora and fauna can be found. A bioblitz of the Elbow Lake property, led by the Kingston Field Naturalists over a 24 hour period in June 2008, tallied a whopping 816 species present on the property – nearly double the biodiversity of other local protected areas.

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question: Q: The Frontenac Arch metamorphic rocks are generally much harder and more resistant to erosion than the younger limestone sedimentary rocks found in the area. Where the Arch crosses the Saint Lawrence River, the resistant knobs and ridges of harder rock sticking up out of the water form the world-famous 1,000 Islands. Occasionally, though, you can still find small isolated patches of softer limestone bedrock sitting on top of the Frontenac Arch. What does the presence of these patches of limestone tell us about the Arch in the past?
contents.answer: A: Isolated “outliers” of limestone dotting the Canadian Shield and Frontenac Arch show that the ocean covered a lot of this area 470 million years ago. There is evidence that as much as 2 kilometres of limestone might have been deposited on top of the Canadian Shield rocks in this area in the past, but it has since almost completely eroded away over the past several hundred million years.

options.label: The patches of limestone were pushed onto the Arch by the glaciers that moved through this area during the Ice Age over 11,000 years ago.

The Arch was originally covered by the ocean 470 million years ago in which the limestone formed.  Most of the soft limestone cover has eroded away, exposing the harder Arch rocks below, but small patches of limestone were sometimes left behind.
The limestone was brought in by early settlers to landscape their farms.

data.title: Horse Stable
data.subtitle: This small, time-worn log building on Spectacle Lake pays homage to the daily life of early settlers.

contents.content_before_fold:
Here the trail ends at scenic little Spectacle Lake. Looking west along this point of land, you will notice an old log building. This site was once used as a temporary base camp for winter wood collection in the area; workers would travel across the frozen lakes and ponds with their horse-drawn sleds, spend two or three days cutting timber to fill the sleds, before returning home. The structure still standing was a stable for the horses, while evidence of the small cottage that once accommodated the people appears to have succumbed to the elements.

Who built these structures and logged the area? Was the timber used for personal purposes, such as homestead building and heating, or was it sold commercially?
contents.content_after_fold:
Although the lands that are now the County of Frontenac have been designated since 1792 (with the County itself being officially established in 1865), the first European settlers didn’t arrive in the Frontenac Arch until the 1830s and 1840s. While minerals were eventually found to be the more profitable resource of the area, it can be assumed that the original forest would have been harvested, at least of its largest trees, around this time. Timber from the forests surrounding Spectacle Lake were brought to Fishing Lake, where the small creek at the lake’s southern end was diverted to accommodate 100’ logs as they made their way via Loughborough Lake to the town of Battersea and beyond.

Settlement of the Elbow Lake property and surrounding lands occurred through the 1870s. Many – but not all – of these settlers were members of the British Army who received grants of land after the War of 1812. The historical atlas for Frontenac County provides a snapshot of land occupation in 1878; while the rugged, sometimes cruel landscape of the Frontenac Arch proved too great a challenge for some settlers, family names such as Convery, Teepell (Teeple), and Young are present in the community to this day. Note that the 200-acre (80 ha.) parcel held by the Canada Company, bisecting the northern arm of Elbow Lake, represented one of the last remaining tracts of land in the area not yet transferred to settlers.

The temporary accommodation on Spectacle Lake is estimated to have been built sometime in the 1940s, possibly by the Miller family, who owned parcels of land in Lots 4 and 5 of the 12th Concession of (the former) Storrington Township from the late 1930s until the early 1950s. By that time, the value of the surrounding forests would not have made commercial logging worthwhile, and so it perhaps most plausible that the cottage and barn provided respite for private individuals harvesting timber for personal use.

1. James Spencer, personal communication to Carolyn Bonta, January 2014.

data.title: Predictors of Frog Calling
data.subtitle: Before you is one example of several stations scattered across QUBS, Elbow Lake and environs to measure local climate and record frog calls.

contents.content_before_fold:
Frogs are potentially very sensitive indicators of environmental change. Evidence from research conducted by Queen’s University and other institutions suggests that some frogs in northeastern North America have begun to emerge and breed markedly earlier over the last few decades, while the geographical ranges of many of many Northern Hemisphere creatures are moving northward, undoubtedly in part in response to climate change.

Since 2005, the Elbow Lake property has supported three automated recording stations for research investigating how frog spring emergence and calling patterns relate to changes in local climate. Over twenty additional stations are present over a broad area covering approximately 2000 km2. At each site, digital data loggers that monitor relative humidity and air, soil and water temperature) are paired with automated Song Meter digital recorders that record frog choruses nightly.

There are nine species of frogs and toads that are found in Eastern Ontario: American toad, American bullfrog, Green frog, Pickerel frog, Mink frog, Northern leopard frog, Boreal chorus frog, Spring peeper, and Gray treefrog. All have distinctive male advertisement calls that can be learned quite easily, and are used as indicators of breeding activity by those wishing to monitor frog populations. Here are photos of four frogs, and their respective calls.

Spring peeper (Pseudacris crucifer)

(click here to play if the above file does not work)

Photo by S. C. Lougheed

Boreal Chorus Frog (Pseudacris maculata)

(click here to play if the above file does not work)

Photo by N. A. Cairns

Gray Treefrog (Hyla versicolor)

(click here to play if the above file does not work)

Photo by M. Conboy

Wood Frog (Lithobates sylvaticus)

(click here to play if the above file does not work)

Photo by S. C. Lougheed

Wood frog recording by N.A. Cairns and M. Szenteczki. All others by A. Cicchino (Queen’s University)

Information gathered over the anticipated 15-year term of the study will provide insight on how climatic and other environmental factors affect frog emergence from hibernation and breeding, and test whether shifts in breeding are occurring over this time scale. The findings of this study will also allow researchers to better predict how different species of Eastern Ontario frogs will respond to continued changes in climate.

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question: Q: Scientific names, although based in Latin or sometimes Greek, often describe a unique characteristic of the organism they represent. Can you guess which frog species found on the Elbow Lake property is capable of changing colour?
contents.answer: A: In blending into their surroundings, the Gray Treefrog may not necessarily be gray in colour – it could be brown or green, pale or dark, or any combination of this spectrum – but this camouflaging ability is appropriately referenced in the scientific name “veriscolor”, or “changeable in colour”.

data.title: Dog-strangling Vine
data.subtitle: Summer visitors might find themselves standing at a flagged-off area at the edge of this trail.

contents.content_before_fold:
In front of you is a management plot controlling Dog-strangling Vine (Cynanchum rossicum, also called Pale Swallowwort or European Swallowwort). This plant is a member of the milkweed family native to Eastern Europe, believed to have been introduced to North America in the late 1800s, possibly as a novel garden plant. In southern Ontario, Dog-strangling Vine (DSV) has become incredibly invasive, with each vine able to grow more than 2 metres in length, twining and climbing in dense mats of vegetation.

In addition to outcompeting native plants for light, water and nutrients – thus negatively affecting native biodiversity and increasing economic losses in forestry and agriculture – DSV also directly impacts wildlife. Monarch butterflies (Danaus plexippus), a species of Special Concern in Canada, depends on native milkweed to feed their larvae; when eggs are laid on DSV, the larvae are unable to sustain themselves on this non-native milkweed and therefore die.

A patch of 30 DSV plants was discovered at this site in June 2014, the largest of three known infestations on the Elbow Lake property. Control measures for DSV are based on the size and density of the infested area; here, Nature Conservancy of Canada (NCC) staff has chosen a combination of seed pod removal and pesticide application in their attempt to eradicate this harmful, invasive plant.
contents.content_after_fold:
To learn more about DSV, we recommend the handbook Best Management Practices in Ontario – Invasive Dog-strangling Vine.

The only other terrestrial invasive species being actively managed on the Elbow Lake property are Garlic Mustard (Alliaria petiolata) and European (or Common) Buckthorn (Rhamnus cathartica). Small invasions of Garlic Mustard have occurred in recent years at a few locations within the developed area of the Elbow Lake Environmental Education Centre and, so far, hand-pulling seems to be an effective control. Buckthorn is much more prevalent on the property, particularly along the laneway and spreading into adjacent natural areas. In 2014, NCC initiated targeted efforts to eradicate Buckthorn through a mix of mechanical and chemical means: Seedlings were hand-pulled, while all larger shrubs were cut at the base, and cut ends were treated with the herbicide Roundup™ Weathermax.

NCC staff and a volunteer applying herbicide to young buckthorn on the Elbow Lake property. (Credit: NCC)

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question: Q: Based on where this patch is found, what do you think are the two most likely means that DSV seeds arrived to colonize this particular site on the Elbow Lake property?
contents.answer: A: At a trailside location more than one kilometre from other known patches, the DSV found here most likely hitchhiked in to the site on the treads of hikers' shoes, or embedded in your pet's fur. It is possible that seeds were blown in by the wind, but they were definitely not deliberately planted here! Invasive, non-native terrestrial plants such as DSV are often found along trails, roadsides and other areas where the native ecosystem has been disturbed by human activity.

data.title: European Frogbit
data.subtitle: This wetland supports many native plants and animals, but has also been heavily invaded by one foreign species… (header image courtesy of NCC)

contents.content_before_fold:
Resembling a small lily pad adorned with lovely little white flowers, European Frogbit (or Common Frogbit; Hydrocharis morsus-ranae) may not immediately stand out among the surrounding wetland vegetation. Multiplying as the growing season progresses, however, by late summer dense mats of European Frogbit may dominate the more exposed surfaces of this pond. 

Outcompeting native plants for space and preventing sunlight from penetrating below the water surface, habitat takeover is in effect! One of the last green floating plants to die off in late fall – European Frog-bit may persist until late October – it also threatens the pond’s fauna: Decomposition uses up valuable oxygen that zooplankton (the smallest of our aquatic animals), invertebrates and fish rely on to survive.
contents.content_after_fold:
Aquatic habitats are prone to invasion by non-native species due to a number of harmful practices: Many serious invaders of the nearby Great Lakes – Zebra Mussel (Dreissena polymorpha), for example – travelled from overseas in the ballast water of ships, only to be discharged when the water was dumped to make room for cargo; unwanted aquarium plants and pets released into local waterbodies may thrive at the expense of the native ecosystem; many plants were even deliberately introduced as ornamental garden plants.

In 1932, to investigate European Frog-bit’s viability in our climates as an ornamental plant, the Central Experimental Farm in Ottawa introduced a small number of plants to its Arboretum ponds, only to find wild-growing plants in the adjacent Rideau Canal soon after. By the 1980s, European Frog-bit had made its way down the Rideau waterway and is now present throughout Southwestern Ontario and beyond.

While control options exist for a number of invasive species, there is currently no recommended control method for European Frog-bit. Mechanical means (e.g., hand pulling) have not been effective, and many herbicides are not approved for in-water use. In the interim, Nature Conservancy of Canada staff has been mapping the spread of European Frog-bit on the Elbow Lake property, and will assess trends as more information is gathered.

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question: Q: European Frogbit isn’t the only water garden specimen that has “escaped” to the wilds of Eastern Ontario. What other ornamental plants have established themselves within the aquatic habitats of our native flora and fauna?
contents.answer:
A: All of these non-native plant species, introduced to North America by unsuspecting gardeners, can now be found in and around various local waterbodies, where they out-compete native species and negatively impact the economy and recreation.

The rapid spread of Purple Loosestrife in the 1980s brought significant public attention to the threat posed by invasive species. In 1992, two species of Eurasian beetle – natural predators of Purple Loosestrife – were released throughout Ontario, and have proved successful in controlling infestations. Purple Loosestrife is present in scattered locations on the Elbow Lake property: Look for it along the eastern shoreline of Elbow Lake. The Common Reed – more often called by its scientific name, Phragmites – has been considerably more aggressive in its take-over of damp areas throughout the province, now nearly ubiquitous at wetland edges and in roadside ditches, and slowly wiping out our native Phragmites. Common Reed can be seen year-round in the vicinity of the Loughborough Lake boat launch on nearby County Road 10.

Only known from one location in Ontario, efforts to control a European Water Chestnut infestation in the Ottawa River have been ongoing since 1998. In 2013, this harmful invader was discovered closer to home, among the wetlands of Wolfe Island on the St. Lawrence River. Meanwhile, Water Soldier is the latest newcomer to severely threaten this part of the province, marching its way along the Trent-Severn Waterway since 2008.

data.title: Elbow Lake Dam
data.long_title: How a Dam Changed Elbow Lake
data.subtitle: You are standing on a relatively small, human-constructed dam... but how big were its impacts on the lake?

contents.content_before_fold: Looking north from the dam, Elbow Lake stretches out before you and disappears around the bend in the distance. A relatively small lake at approximately 48 ha (119 acres) in current surface area, Elbow Lake is also quite shallow, reaching a maximum depth of hardly 10 m immediately below the climate station raft at the north end. Bathymetry mapping of Elbow Lake, carried out most recently by QUBS in 2012, shows that the whole southern arm of the lake is less than 2 m deep. This wasn’t always the case, however. In fact, much of the southern arm was never part of Elbow Lake! The dam you stand at now was built in 1984-85 by the Hewlett-Packard Company, who previously owned and managed the Elbow Lake property as a corporate retreat, with the intent of artificially maintaining consistently high water levels during the summer months for recreational purposes. This dam flooded what was once a wetland south of the original Elbow Lake.
contents.content_after_fold:
The Hewlett-Packard-constructed dam wasn’t the first man-made dam to impact water levels in Elbow Lake. A close look at mapping for Storrington Township, circa 1878, shows a road allowance (narrow strip of undeeded land) bisecting the southern tip of the original Elbow Lake. For current reference, the ELEEC’s Day Lodge building sits on the road allowance – with the existing lake now stretching further south beyond this point. Aerial imagery from the late 1950s suggests Elbow Lake was only about two thirds its current size.

Sometime in the late 1960s a dam was constructed further downstream along the outlet creek, holding back water and flooding the wetland and low areas south of Elbow Lake. The purpose of this historic dam is unknown; no evidence of its existence remains.

Natural water level fluctuations contribute to healthy, productive riparian areas – that narrow band of shoreline that isn’t fully terrestrial and isn’t fully aquatic, but is incredibly important for the life that relies on both of these habitats to complete their life cycle. Constructed dams and active water level management do not promote natural fluctuations in water level. One action item in the Nature Conservancy of Canada’s Property Management Plan for Elbow Lake is to study how the dam’s control of water level affects the lake ecosystem; this will help determine the feasibility of removing the dam and returning a healthy, natural ecological balance to the Elbow Lake.

Depth map of Elbow Lake. Ontario Base Map (OBM) digital basedata provided by Government of Ontario at 1:10,000 scale. © Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada. Reproduced with permission. Data compiled by Queen's University Biological Station at varying scales (current to 2012). Prepared by Kellie Heney

contents.title: Gallery 1
contents.description: A collection of aerial snapshots of the lake over time, from 1953 to 1962 to 1978. (swipe the images to move around in the gallery)

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question: Q: Different species of fish within a single body of water are often segregated by behaviour, habitat or food preference; this enables each species to have its own “niche”, thus avoiding competition with similar species. Which of Elbow Lake’s fish species do you think might rely on the shallow, soft-bottomed and vegetation-laden wetland areas as the primary habitat for their full life cycle?
contents.answer:
A: The warm and weedy waters of the southern tip and northeastern arm of Elbow Lake are the preferred habitat for Redbelly Dace, our sole representative of the minnow family. With a preference for soft organic substrates, the 3-7 cm long Redbelly Dace avoids competition with other species of small fish – Logperch and Tesselated Darter – that inhabit areas with sandy, gravelly substrates. Largemouth Bass are found in every habitat within Elbow Lake, from the shallow wetland areas to the rocky shoreline to deeper waters.

High school students capture all of the above fish species when seine netting various habitats under the ELEEC’s Aquatic Diversity program.

title: Main Facility and Off the Trails

data.title: Old Bird Microphone
data.subtitle: On spring nights, the loud call of the Whip-poor-will may keep you awake; in fall, the silence of the night may lull you to sleep.  But there may be much more going on in the sky above the cabins…

contents.content_before_fold:
Massive migrations of birds occur at night across much of the Americas in spring and fall, perhaps involving as many as 5 billion individual birds. Many species give short vocalizations as they fly, possibly for echolocation (using the echo of sound waves to guide navigation), to maintain contact with other migrating birds particularly of their own kind, and to maintain spacing to avoid mid-air collisions in flight. While most of these calls take place above the average altitude of the terrain and are not easily heard by the human ear, a microphone can help tune in and amplify flight calls of migrating birds.

In fall 2014, a microphone was installed at ELEEC to record the calls of birds flying over the facility. Software designed by Old Bird Inc., the company of independent researcher William R. Evans of New York State, will sort out the number of calls and identify them to species. Target species are night-migrating thrushes, sparrows and warblers. The goal of the Old Bird project is to establish permanent, long-term acoustic (sound) monitoring stations continent-wide and use these to evaluate long-term trends in numbers of the focal species.
contents.content_after_fold:
ELEEC is currently the most northern site within a regional network of recording stations tracking bird migration patterns. Initially confined to New York State, recording stations now form an acoustic monitoring transect across eastern North America and increasingly beyond. The data recorded at ELEEC will be integrated into this network, contributing to a bigger picture of bird migration throughout our region. Over the longer term, changes in migration patterns and abundances of individual bird species may be detected.

At this stage of the Old Bird project, flight call data are being gathered and stored in a temporary archive of sound files. As the number of recording stations has grown, the current volume of raw data has become more than one researcher can manage and analyze, and efforts are now focused on automating the process. This will make it easier for partners to participate in the project, and will also enable studies comparing migration data both within and across monitoring sites.

Following automation, the flight call data will be made available to high school students to enhance teaching and learning opportunity at ELEEC, as well as for the listening pleasure of visitors curious to know what species of birds are migrating overhead at the time of their visit.

contents.content_before_fold:
Overnight Flight Calls on October 11-12, 2014

On the night of October 11, 2014, the Old Bird microphone recorded 52 night flight calls.

Approximately six hours after the evening’s recording started (i.e., 1:00 am in the early morning hours of Saturday, October 12), a few Swainson’s Thrush calls were recorded, along with some weak Hermit Thrush calls in the background. Listen closely: Do you hear a “honk” sound toward the end of that clip? That was a juvenile Great-horned Owl!

Swainson’s Thrush

(click here to play if the above file does not work)

The audio recordings from the Old Bird microphone are analyzed by matching the graphical representations of calls (sonograms) to known calls of specific thrush, sparrow and warbler species. Other species detected migrating overhead in the early morning hours of October 12 included White-Throated Sparrow at approximately 3:00 am, and Gray-cheeked Thrush about a half hour later.

White-Throated Sparrow

(click here to play if the above file does not work)

Gray-cheeked Thrush

(click here to play if the above file does not work)

After a night of flying, migrating birds will descend from flying altitude to land for a rest; in the case of thrushes, they call during descent. Shortly before the sun began to rise around 6:45 am on this particular Saturday morning, a Hermit Thrush can be heard beginning its descent over the Elbow Lake Environmental Education Centre.

Hermit Thrush Descent

(click here to play if the above file does not work)

Photo: Hermit Thrush. (Credit: M. Conboy, QUBS)

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question: Q: What do you think is the main reason that thrushes, warblers and sparrows migrate from Canada to more southern climates each fall?
contents.answer: A: Animal migration is driven by the need for resources, in particular food and breeding habitat. Being mobile, animals can move from areas with fewer resources to areas with greater resources. In fall, the breeding season is over but food – e.g. berries, insects – is becoming scarce. Time to find food! While freezing temperatures do pose real challenges for maintaining core body temperatures, as long as birds can gain sufficient energy food, even the smallest ones are able to tolerate the cold.

options.label: Winter is coming, and they must escape the cold temperatures!
The habitat is better for raising their young.

data.title: Project FeederWatch
data.subtitle: Bird feeders are maintained year-round at the patio outside the Pavilion. (header image courtesy of Mark Conboy)

contents.content_before_fold:
This bird feeding area was registered as a count site for Project FeederWatch in fall 2013. Part of a North America-wide Citizen Science initiative, this project documents the birds that visit our feeders through the winter months, ultimately contributing to greater overall knowledge of the health and population distributions of wild birds, and monitoring broad-scale trends in abundance of individual species.

November through March, the most common bird species visiting the Elbow Lake feeders are Black-capped Chickadee (Poecile atricapillus), White-breasted Nuthatch (Sitta carolinensis), Blue Jay (Cyanocitta cristata), Downy Woodpecker (Picoides pubescens), Hairy Woodpecker (Picoides villosus), American Goldfinch (Spinus tristis), Purple Finch (Haemorhous purpureus) and Dark-eyed Junco (Junco hyemalis). This poster can help guide your identification of common winter feeder birds in our area.

Project Feederwatch will continue at Elbow Lake for the long term. Over the years, students from visiting school groups will be able to explore our Count Site’s data from an on-line repository, potentially using it for further study and analysis.
contents.content_after_fold:
The following videos were taken in early spring at our Project FeederWatch count site. This particular feeder is stocked with black-oil sunflower, a favourite food of our avian visitors. Compare the “grab and go” feeding style of the Black-capped Chickadee with the “stay and eat” feeding style of the finches. Note, too, the emerging bright yellow feathers on the American Goldfinches feeding alongside the Purple Finch. In this particular video, the red feathers of the Purple Finch indicate that this individual is a male.

Black-Capped Chickadee (Poecile atricapillus)

(click here to play if the above file does not work)

American Goldfinch (Carduelis tristis)

(click here to play if the above file does not work)

Purple Finch (Haemorhous purpureus)

(click here to play if the above file does not work)

Want to learn more about winter feeder birds? Contact the ELEEC for programming options!

contents.content_before_fold: Project FeederWatch asks participants to document the maximum number of birds of a species that visit the feeder area during a designated count period. Try sitting quietly and watching the feeders for 10 minutes. Use this modified Project FeederWatch tally sheet to help document your count. What is your final tally of birds?

contents.title: Quiz
contents.question: Q: Different species of bird have different food preferences. The birds that visit the feeders at this count site have a preferred diet that typically includes (check all that you think might apply):
contents.answer: A: The birds that visit the Pavilion feeders are primarily seed-eaters (but some are also primarily insect-eaters e.g. woodpeckers). Some – such as Purple Finch – will also eat berries when available. Blue jays are omnivorous – eating everything from the seed that we provide here through insects, bird eggs, and even small vertebrates when possible. Every now and then, a Sharp-shinned Hawk (Accipiter striatus) or Cooper’s Hawk (Accipiter cooperii) will visit these feeders… not in search of seed, but in search of small birds to eat!
